chunks.original_latin:
I.
Epistola sancti Dionysii Areopagitae Gajo monacho
missa.
chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    One<break time="500ms"/>    <s>
      This is a letter from Saint Dionysius the Areopagite to the monk Gaius.
    </s>
<break time="1s"/>
</speak>

Darkness becomes even more obscure in the presence of light, especially with a lot of light. Similarly, ignorance hides knowledge, and even more so with abundant knowledge.

These concepts are incredibly profound, but should not be seen as a lack; appreciate them deeply, for they are hidden within those who possess the light. True knowledge, according to God, is ignorance, and the darkness surrounding Him is cloaked by all light, concealing all knowledge.

If someone thinks they understand God by seeing Him, they haven't truly contemplated Him, but instead have perceived something else that exists and is known through Him. He, however, exists beyond mind and essence, not known or seen in the usual sense, and is recognized beyond essence and beyond mind. This superior state is perfect ignorance, which is the knowledge of Him beyond all known things.
chunks.original_latin:
Tenebrae quidem obscurae fiunt lumine, et magis
multo lumine. Ignorantiam occultant scientiae, et
magis multae scientiae. Haec supereminenter, sed
non secundum privationem accipiens, approba supervere,
quia latet habentes ὂν lumen, et vere scientia
secundum Deum ignorantia, et superpositae
ipsius tenebrae velantur ab omni lumine, et abscondunt
omnem scientiam. Et si quis videns Deum
intellexit quod vidit, non ipsum contemplatus est,
sed quid eorum ab ipso existentium et cognitorum. Ipse autem super animum et essentiam supercollocatus,
universaliter non cognoscendo neque videndo,
 et est superessentialiter, et super animum cognoscitur. Et ipsa secundum quod melius perfectissima
ignorantia scientia est ejus super omnia cognita.
